g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Implications of differences in AFOLU CO
fluxes between global models and National
global models (this number relates to an IAMs comparison for the period 2005
in this Chapter; for comparison with other models see Figure
stimates comparable, can build confidence in land
the purpose of assessing collective progress in the
occurring in forests (Grassi et al. 2021). This difference is potentially a consequence of: (i) simplified
representation of management in global models
concerning impacts of forest management in biomass expansion and thickening
(ii) inaccurate and/or incomplete estimation of LULUCF fluxes in NGHGIs
, especially in developing countries, primarily in non
forest land uses and in soils,
tual differences in how global models and NGHGIs define ‘anthropogenic’ CO
. The impacts of (i) and (ii) are difficult to quantify and result in
uncertainties that will decrease slowly over time through imp
rovements of both models and NGHGIs.
By contrast, the inconsistencies in (iii) and its resulting biases were assessed as explained below.
Since changing the NGHGIs’ approach is impractical, an interim method to translate and adjust the
els was outlined for reconciling a bookkeeping model and NGHGIs
. More recently, an improved version of this approach has been applied to the future mitigation
in this Chapter. This method implies a post
global models’ results that addresses two components of the conceptual differences in the
flux; (i) how the impact of human
effects) are considered, and (ii) the extent
of forest area considered ‘managed’. Essentially, this
approach adds DGVM estimates of CO
fluxes due to indirect effects from countries
intact forest area maps as a proxy) to the original global models’ anthropogenic land
